title: Home
text:
This companion site for the 420-6P3 course includes:


Lecture slides / documents
Exercises
References & Resources


Website accessible at john-abbott-college.github.io/6P3-Notes


This course will introduce students to the principles of the Internet of Things (IoT). Students will use Linux and Python to program a Raspberry Pi in order to read data from sensors and control actuators.
By the end of the course, students build and deploy an IoT product that is securely connected to the Azure ecosystem in order to collect and analyse telemetry data as well as respond to remote commands.




Experience using Object Oriented Programming to create applications in any language.
Familiarity using the Bash shell and basic Linux CLI.
Familiarity with Python.
A Raspberry Pi with various sensors and actuators (see page Hardware List).
A Microsoft Azure account: create a free Azure for Students account if necessary.
VS Code configured for Python programming and remote development (see page Dev Setup).




This webpage is written in Markdown using the Quarto framework. The website is hosted via GitHub Pages
Source code is open source and available on GitHub.


Create a local copy of these notes:

Install Quarto for your system
Clone the course GitHub repository.
Preview the website:
quarto preview .

title: Course Hardware
text:
The reTerminal is a development board based on the Raspberry Pi Compute Module 4 (CM4) manufactured by Seeed Studio.





The reTerminal device.


Notable features:

Compute Module 4 with 4GB RAM & 32GB eMMC
5-Inch IPS capacitive multi-touch screen at 1280 x 720 and 293 PPI
Wireless connectivity with dual-band 2.4GHz/5GHz Wi-Fi and Bluetooth 5.0 BLE
Cryptographic co-processor with secure hardware-based key storage
Built-in modules such as accelerometer, light sensor, and RTC


See reTerminal Wiki page for detailed specs and documentation








RPI USB-C POWER SUPPLY BLACK US


The reTerminal requires a power supply that can provide a minimum of 3 Amps. The official Raspberry Pi USB-C Power Supply in included in the kit.

title: Course Hardware
text:
2 Compute Module 4





Raspberry PI CM 4


The Compute Module 4 (CM4) made by the Raspberry Pi Foundation is powering the reTerminal.
Notable features:

Processor: Broadcom BCM2711 quad-core Cortex-A72 (ARM v8) 64-bit SoC @ 1.5GHz


See CM4 datasheet for details.

See Difference Between ARM64, ARMel, and ARMhf for more info on the different ARM architectures.

2.1 Grove Base Hat for Raspberry Pi





Grove Base Hat for GPIO connections


In a typical Raspberry Pi, sensors would be connected via the 40-pin GPIO.
To facilitate connections of the Grove sensors, this “Hat” (term for an add-on board of the Raspberry Pi) includes the following types of connection:

6 Digital
4 Analog
3 I2C
1 PWM
1 UART


See Grove base hat Wiki for details.

title: Course Hardware
text:
3 Sensors

3.1 AHT20 I2C Temperature & Humidity





AHT20 I2C temperature/humidity sensor


See AHT20 I2C Industrial Grade Temperature & Humidity Sensor wiki for details.

Temperature measurement range -40 ~ 85°C, Humidity measurement range 0 ~ 100% RH.
Digital output, Grove I2C interface.



3.2 AHT20 Libraries
The main module for this sensor is provided by Seeed in this Github repository and can be installed with the grove.py library.
Follow official Step by step installation for python 3 (see below). Don’t use the one-click installation or it will install to the wrong location
git clone [https://github.com/Seeed-Studio/grove.py](https://github.com/Seeed-Studio/grove.py)
cd grove.py
sudo pip3 install .
Alternatively, it’s also possible to use Adafruit’s adafruit-circuitpython-ahtx0 library to communicate with the sensor (see library’s Pypi page). However, to instantiate the provided sensor class, you will need to pass it an I2C bus instance. To instantiate an I2C bus instance, install and use the adafruit-extended-bus library (see Pypi page).

title: Course Hardware
text:
4 Actuators & Motors

4.1 LED Socket





LED


LED in a removable socket and potentiometer for power adjustment. LED can be swapped with different colors.
See LED wiki page for details.


4.2 Cooling Fan





Cooling Fan


5V Cooling Fan 40mm x 10mm with 2-pin JST connector.

See product page here.



4.3 Relay





Relay switch


A digital switch. Controls the on/off flow of electricity with a small digital signal.

Operate voltage: 3.3V-5V
Input current: 100mA
Rated load: 5A@250VAC 5A@30VDC

See relay wiki page for details.

title: Course Hardware
text:
5 Cabling
The following cables are included in the base kit:

Grove Universal 4 Pin Buckled 5cm Cable.
Grove Universal 4 Pin Buckled 20cm Cable.
Grove 4 pin Female Jumper to Grove 4 pin Cable
Grove 4 pin Male Jumper to Grove 4 pin Cable
40-pin flat ribbon cable 20cm (female-female).
2-pin JST SM Plug, one end open.

title: Course software
text:
The operating system running inside the reTerminal is Raspberry Pi OS, which is based on Debian Linux.
We will make use of the following tools:

bash and python and related packaging tools
git and related configuration
a Unix shell and package manager for installing and managing dependencies compatible with RasperryPi OS
(later this semester) Azure and GitHub CLI tools
(later this semester) .NET for interfacing with the App Dev III code

We will achieve that in one of the following ways, depending on the computer you are using:

(on Windows computers such as the lab computers) by creating a Debian WSL container
(on OS X computers) using brew
(on Linux computers) using your system package manager.

See below for further instructions for each.


If using a Windows machine (lab computers and/or personal) for this course, you will need to set up Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).

Install Debian on WSL

Choosing Debian as the Linux distribution
Set up Windows Terminal
Set up VS Code
Set up git

Install dependencies:

# Update system:
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y
# Verify python version is >= 3.9: 
python3 --version
# Ensure pip is installed:
sudo apt install python3-pip
pip3 --version
